back: Given $n$-vectors $\mathbf{x}$ and $\mathbf{y}$, the dot product or inner product is denoted $\mathbf{x} \cdot \mathbf{y}$ or $\mathbf{x}^T \mathbf{y}$ and is the scalar value given by multiplying corresponding components and summing them up: \begin{equation*} \mathbf{x} \cdot \mathbf{y} = \sum_{i=0}^{n-1} x_i y_i. \end{equation*}

$\mathbf{A} \mathbf{B}$ is defined if the inner dimensions agree, and the output is a $k \times m$ matrix $\mathbf{C} = \mathbf{A} \mathbf{B}$, where the $k,m$th entry of $\mathbf{C}$ is given by $c_{k,m} = \mathbf{a}_{k*} \cdot \mathbf{b}_m$.
A (real) square matrix whose columns are a set of orthonormal vectors.
For a matrix $\mathbf{A}$, the Gram matrix is the matrix whose $i,j$th entry is the dot product of columns $i$ and $j$ of $\mathbf{A}$. The Gram matrix can be calculated as $\mathbf{A}^T \mathbf{A}$.
A matrix $\mathbf{M}$ is symmetric if the $i,j$th element is equal to the $j,i$th element for any valid $i$ and $j$. Equivalently, $\mathbf{M}^T = \mathbf{M}$.
